Award.AwardTitle: Data-driven Modeling of Equilibrium and Non-equilibrium Statistics
Award.AbstractNarration:
An important issue in applied and computational sciences is to find the essential reduced models to predict variables of interests from high-dimensional complex dynamical systems. Given our advanced capability to collect big data, an important challenge is to leverage the information carried by the data to improve the modeling effort. Computationally, this requires adequate inference of appropriate parameters such that their uncertainties are quantifiable. A much more challenging yet important issue is to be able to make prediction in the presence of external disturbances. This problem has a wide range of applications such as in climate change science where one is interested to predict the climate change statistics corresponding to exogenous forcing such as the volcanic eruptions or even the anthropogenic factor such as the human activities. The projects in this proposal are to address these issues. While the developed methodology is aimed for general modeling of multi-scale phenomena, our focus will be to improve the understanding and prediction of the deformation behavior of graphene.

Two projects are proposed: 1. Data-driven reduced modeling paradigms to capture coarse grained statistical solutions of the underlying dynamics. The methodology involves the Mori-Zwanzig formalism, a precise description of the memory effect to take into account the interactions between processes occurring on different physical scales, and a data-driven numerical scheme for estimating the parameters of the stochastic reduced model. 2. Estimation of parameters in the reduced models to predict changes on the statistical solutions in the presence of small external disturbances. This project involves employing the Pad√® approximation on appropriate integral operators and designing efficient algorithm to solve a system of nonlinear equations that respect appropriate equilibrium statistics of the unperturbed data, leveraging the formulation from the fluctuation-dissipation theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modeling complex dynamical systems usually involve proposing a model based on some physical laws, estimating the model parameters from the available observed data, and verifying the results against observables. An important practical issue in modeling is that models are subjected to error, whether it is due to incomplete physical understanding, misspecification of parameters, or numerical discretization. The proposed project in this proposal is to devise parameter estimation methods that can be use in the presence of model errors. The completion of this project involves a systematic development of a parameter estimation method, leveraging the linear response statistics formulated through fluctuation-dissipation theory. Theoretically, we established the identifiability of the parameters through appropriate response statistics. Computationally, we devised an approximate nonlinear least-square algorithm with theoretical guarantee under mild assumption. Finally, and most importantly, this algorithm has been extended to the problems with model error. In this case, we demonstrated that on a coarse-grained molecular dynamic and on a severely truncated PDE?s with spatio-temporal chaotic solution, the resulting models with the estimated parameters are able to predict the nonlinear statistical response of the dynamics under admissible external disturbances.

During the course of this project, we developed various technical tools that are directly used to achieve this goal. Additionally, we have also pursued several research problems related to (and motivated by the outcomes) of the originally proposed projects, which are listed below.

Fitting model parameters through linear response statistics require the knowledge of the equilibrium distribution function of the underlying dynamics. In practice, such information is not available, especially when the underlying systems are nonlinear, high-dimensional, and/or non-Gaussian. What is usually available is a time series of low-dimensional observables of the systems. Given such constraints, we have developed a non-parametric estimator for the linear response statistics. We found that the resulting model in which the parameters are fitted to these statistical response estimates can predict the full nonlinear response statistics in the presence of model error.

An Equation-By-Equation (EBE) scheme was developed to find a density functions by matching statistical moments. While this numerical method was designed to estimate parameters that responsible for the equilibrium property of the dynamics, it is a general method that can be used to find real roots of system of nonlinear equations, provided such roots exist. In our test, we have demonstrated the effectiveness of this technique on solving a system of 300 integral equations of seven dimensional functions.

A data-driven nonparametric likelihood function for parameter estimation. This numerical method was invented to overcome the expensive computational cost in repetitive evaluations of the likelihood function, as required in many parameter estimation schemes, e.g., least-squares or Markov Chain Monte-Carlo algorithms. In the situation when such function is not known, the proposed technique produces an estimator that is provably consistent with the underlying likelihood function if the latter exists and respects the geometry of the data.

A reduced-order modeling technique for non-equilibrium transport processes in a quantum device with infinite baths. The complex nature of these devices, especially the bath, as well as the length/time scale associated with the transport process, suggest that their properties are sensitive to chemical details and quantum mechanical models are the most appropriate description. A systematic approach has been developed to derive a finite, open quantum system, in which the influence from the baths is implicitly incorporated.

For applications such as the groundwater flow and oil reservoir simulations, the underlying model can be naturally described by partial differential equations (PDE?s) defined on a non-flat domain. For inverse problems in this setting, e.g., the estimation of permeability, the cost of evaluating the corresponding likelihood function is directly related to the complexity of the PDE solvers. To overcome this issue, we designed a novel PDEs solver, inspired by operator estimation methods that were invented for manifold learning.

Through the projects in this award, the PIs have mentored four undergraduate students, five graduate students, and two postdoctoral researchers. This award funded three undergraduate students in a summer research program three graduate students as research assistants. PIs organized an REU in Applied Mathematics and Scientific Computations in Summer 2018. We should note that PSU math is not an NSF REU site and this program is partially supported by this award. The REU recruited 9 students. The total number of papers includes one published book, 9 published peer-reviewed articles, and 4 papers are under review. Beyond these formal publications, the PIs have disseminated the results through various conference and seminar presentations.
